Message.Msg: M&A splash highlights corporate cash piles, sidelined money. "For retail investors, there's a real cost to having your money on the sidelines," Sandler said. "Corporations are just saying: 'I can't sit on this cash anymore.' Money sitting around doing nothing subtracts return on equity." Postrecession, it's no longer acceptable for a corporation to have more than 10% of its value tied up in cash, Sandler said. This much was evidenced by the suit brought against Apple Inc. ( AAPL ) by activist investor David Einhorn.

Message.Title: Bloomberg: AAPL IPhones/iPad Sales Booming in China
Message.Msg: See full article on Bloomberg -- sales of iPhones and iPads in China are surging in many Chinese cities monitored by the Ministry located in Nanjing. Great news for after following the Chinese ministry urging citizens to exercise restraint on restaurant, beverage and fireworks consumption for the Chinese NY celebrations resulting in less sales yoy in those sectors, but sales of AAPL products are booming in many Chinese cities being monitored by the Ministry. Excerpt: Restaurant Sales Sales of “high end” electronics, including Apple Inc.’s iPad and iPhone, jumped 36 percent in shops monitored by the ministry in the eastern city of Nanjing, according to the statement. In contrast, spending at “high-end” restaurants in the eastern province of Zhejiang dropped by more than 20 percent, the ministry said. The data are based on sales at “major retail and restaurant outlets” monitored by the ministry, according to yesterday’s statement, which didn’t specify the number of stores or whether the figures were adjusted for inflation. The cities of Beijing, Shanghai and Nanjing, and the central and eastern provinces of Shandong, Henan, Hebei, Zhejiang and Hubei were mentioned in the report.

Message.Title: The problem with apple
Message.Msg: They make great products but competition is rising. Smart phones are still a growth industry but apple's increase in growth is less than the increase in growth of other makers, hence compeition is seeping in. Apple enjoys a huge margin on their products including their biggest earnings item, the iphone. But as competitors come in with products that are cheaper and "good enough", they are seeing increasing sales at apple's expense. No longer is apple the only quality phone around. Phone companies are subsidizing apple's phones and taking a hit on their earnings and as there are more products available they will be able to either push other phones or push back against the subsidies. Apple's margins are not sustainable and they'll be forced to cut their prices. To illustrate how shrinking margins can hurt apple: To take some numbers out of the air: Say a company makes an item with a cost of $300 and is able to sell it for $600. Fantastic for earnings. But as competition eeks in and they are no longer the only game in town, they cut the item to $550, still $250 profit is not that bad. Other phone makers don't make nearly that much, they are out for market share for the moment. If the company sold 1000 of these items at a profit of $300, they would make $30000. But cutting the price to $250 means they only make $25000 on those 1000 items. They can make up for that by selling 120 items which is doable in a growth industry. Fine......... still the same profit. If the items are cut another $50, the company still makes $20000 on those 1000 items, still very good but they would now have to sell 150 of the same items to make the $30000 they originally would have made if the product were able to be sold at a profit of $300. If you think ASPs won't come down, you're most likely sitting with blinders on. If you think competitors can't hurt apple because they don't make money, sorry, but they can. Ask the US automakers how they dismissed the Japanese automakers who they felt had cheap products only to find they eventually made good quality items, even in the upscale "luxury" market once they established themselves. If you think apple will maintain their quality, maybe so, maybe not. Ask honda who had their Civic as the number one rated car by consumer reports year in and year out and completely fell off the recommended list as they cut quality and what happened? Along come other newer competitors. I used to have only Sony Trinitrons. My parents only had Zenith. Now as I sit here typing, I have a Samsung TV sitting next to me. Did I buy it because it was Samsung? No. I bought it because TVs have become a comodity item and it had a decent name and the price was right. Smart phones are becoming a commodity item just as tvs did, just as pcs did. This is why apple is falling. Take a look at earnings estimates for apple: This quarter: $10.24 vs earnings last year, same quarter of $12.30. Next quarter: $9.78 vs earnings last year of $9.32 Yes, apple makes fantastic products but no longer are they the only game in town. Yes, smartphones are still growing but margins are not sustainable. How much they come down is key to what happens to apple earnings. Yes, apple looks like it has a very low pe............................ provided earnings don't shrink. But the growth rate of apple is going down as happens to all large companies. Smart phones are becoming a commodity and consumer upgrades are lengthening as new products aren't enough to push people to pay for the newest hottest thing. That is why apple is falling and why the pe looks so fantastic........ for now.

Message.Title: IPhone 5 Sets China Record With 2 Million Sales in Three Days
Message.Msg: Apple Inc. (AAPL) said the iPhone 5 posted record sales in its first weekend of availability in China, the world’s largest mobile-phone market by users. Apple sold more than 2 million of its latest handsets in the three days following its Dec. 14 introduction in the country, Apple said in a statement today. Carolyn Wu, a Beijing- based spokeswoman for Apple, said she didn’t have comparable data to release on initial sales in China of previous models. Apple fell to its lowest price in 10 months on Dec. 14 after Steven Milunovich, an analyst at UBS AG in New York, cut his price estimate for the shares, citing concern that growth may slow for the iPhone and iPad. The iPhone 5 may not sell as well as the previous model in China, Milunovich said in a report. The China sales are part of the fastest iPhone roll-out yet, with the device scheduled for introduction in 100 countries by Dec. 31, Apple said in today’s statement. “Customer response to iPhone 5 in China has been incredible,” Apple’s Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook said in the statement. “China is a very important market for us and customers there cannot wait to get their hands on Apple products.” The company’s flagship store in Beijing’s Sanlitun district was pelted with eggs in January when it didn’t open as scheduled for the first day of sales for the iPhone 4S. Demand for the iPhone in China was “staggering,” and the company “didn’t bet high enough,” Cook said Jan. 24. To eliminate the risk of a recurrence with sales of the iPhone 5, Apple introduced a registration system that required buyers to reserve a device online before it could be picked up in Apple stores.

Message.Title: AAPL Sales up 400% India, 2012 vs. 2011
Message.Msg: Apple never sold much in India, which is Samsung country, as most customers can't even afford a smartphone, and barely a cell-phone. But this past year Apple started to make a bit of sales push there. Its smartphones went from 1% of India's mobile-phone market in 2011 to now being 4%. 400% growth in just one year! Now assume that growth rate halves the next two years, still means by start of 2015 APPLE WILL HAVE 15 - 16% of the market in India. Not as good as in USA where Apple has 51% you say. OK, but India has 1.2 billion people. Even 15% of that is nearly 200 million people!. If Apple can get half or most of the professional and businessman class and lawyers...etc. as its customers in India.... Apple will make tons of $ and tons of growth. Same in China... but Apple already has 7 - 8% of the market in Mainland China, bit further along.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: “Apple was firmly in the spotlight again this week following CEO Tim Cook’s comments at the Goldman Sachs Technology and Internet conference on Tuesday,” James Rogers reports for TheStreet. “Despite the phenomenal success of the iPhone and iPad, Cook used a question-and-answer session with Goldman analyst Bill Shope to explain that Apple’s more than a mere hardware company,” Rogers reports. “‘Because we’re not a hardware company, we have other ways to make money and reward shareholders,” he said, adding that Apple generated $3.7 billion in software and services revenue last quarter. ‘If you look at that compared to software and services companies, it’s an incredible amount of revenue.’” Rogers reports, “Cook noted the purchase of an Apple device opens the door to additional revenue for the company. “‘We don’t look at the sale of a product as the last part of our relationship with a customer,’ he said. ‘It’s the first.’”

Topic.Title: Apple should be 500/share based on China alone...

Message.Msg: I do have 500 shares.. .way over leveraged but my buy in price is 600. I tend to make large bets each year, and so far have done well. I know all eggs in one basket is usually a recipe for disaster, but I completely expect large losses in the short term. I held SIRI from 1 dollar to 5 cents then back up to 2 dollars before selling. I also held Bank of America from 7 dollars down to 5 then up to 11. I made the mistake of selling Apple during the 2008 crash at 90/share before its eventual historic run after the iphone. I won't make the same mistake twice. I'm ok holding all the way down to 350 if need be. I know banks will manipulate the price, but they will not get my shares in the process.

Topic.Title: Apple should be 500/share based on China alone...

Message.Msg: quite a typo... my buy in price is 460 (avg), not 600.. but even if it was 600 I wouldn't be overly panicking. After seeing SIRI lose 95% of it's value then double from my buy in price it taught me that day to day pricing is subject to manipulation but eventually the market has to reward a stock for it's value.

Topic.Title: have you even compared sound quality iphone vs nokia?

Message.Msg: I have never compared sound quality, but since all phone share the same cell phone protocols, any difference would be in a very limited part of the phone hardware. Sound quality is based on a set of technologies that were mature 40 years ago, not much moat there for Nokia if Apple could spend a little bit of money and improve it. Also, based on the fact that people choose cell phones over land lines, I don't think that sound quality is that important to most people.

Topic.Title: have you even compared sound quality iphone vs nokia?

Message.Msg: Have you even realized that in iPhone 5 when you are speaking in noisy background, the speakers change to Noise Reduction speakers and you can hear much clearer. I am not sure why Apple did not publicize such innovative functions in their products.
